description.narrative: Iraq has been experiencing many years of violent conflict. This has caused a shrinking of civic space, deteriorating human rights situation, unresolved past conflict and gender inequality. The SCC program in Iraq will address the damaged inter-community relations and the relation between state and citizens. Thereby empowering survivors and victims of violence to advocate for their rights with regards to justice and accountability. The main focus of the program lies on the Ninewa governorate, which was hit hardest by ISIL. Capacity-building training will be provided focusing on human rights, gender, dealing with the past, and advocacy.

The activity is part of a larger programme implemented by the Strengthening Civil Courage Alliance, consisting of ABAAD – Resource Center for Gender Equality, Amnesty International The Netherlands, DefendDefenders, PAX and their partner networks.

The main objective is to reach evidence-based advocacy of strong and diverse victim groups and other civil society group in Iraq, that contribute to the realisation of inclusive transformative justice processes and to the nun-recurrence of atrocities. More specifically, the program aims for the victims and survivors of human rights abuses and violent conflict in Ninewa to influence transformative justice and accountability processes to be more inclusive. Secondly, the goal is to reach an increased collaboration between inclusive victim and survivor groups across the political divide, and finally, the programme aims to strengthen international standards and due diligence on arms export control.

The target groups are marginalised survivor and victim groups; Iraqi partner organisations; grantees, such as community-based organisations; a network of advocates; local and provincial authorities; national authorities; and international policymakers.

description.narrative: In all phases of the programming cycle (planning, designing, implementing, monitoring, evaluation), CSOs take steps to improve the participation of marginalized people (especially women, girls, and youth), and consider how to dismantle the attitudes, laws, customs, and institutions that sustain the exclusion of marginalized people)

comment.narrative: Both Iraqi partners employ a number of women and youth, who are then also involved in different stages of programming. However, 'hard' decision making - e.g. on staff and employment, budget, and shifts in strategic focus - are in reality made by select number of senior staff members, typically men aged 40 and older.

While no concrete implementation has been done yet, PAX and partners have launched the initiative to develop one action plan per Iraqi partner to drastically improve accountability and safety mechanisms within each organization. Following the PSEAH training, the two partner CSOs filled-in an extensive PSEAH self-assessment tool and shared it with the Alliance partners.

In 2022, the plan is to identify the gaps for each partner, and translate these into concrete action points to tackle on an internal level - therefore elaborating an action plan with a respective mechanism to monitor its implementation.

comment.narrative: National-level authorities (parliament) are seated/elected, but without acting government, no tangible action can be determined by Iraqi partners.

Goal is to be decided through strategy sessions with network of advocates (SO2), Iraqi partners, PAX, Amnesty, and knowledge partners. However, tentatively, the goal is to create direct interaction between grass-root/victim organizations or initiatives and national-level authorities (e.g. in Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Migration and Displacement, etc.), brokered by international- and Iraqi partners, the latter which will have a leading role. Change target is openness of Iraqi authorities to victims, which must increase over politically and exclusively oriented policy makers.

title.narrative: # of times that Iraqi partner CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/ or creating space to engage (SCS3)

comment.narrative: One Iraqi partner regularly engages with national-level authorities on priorities emerging from civil society gatherings and projects, including those with PAX. Topics include freedom and protection of activists and the YPS 2250 agenda. Another Iraqi partner is less active on the national level (assumption). This needs to be further clarified through the L&A assessment, planned for July 2022 (target starts 2023).

For sub-national level authorities, the goal is to 'recruit' them as allies (representing their provincial citizen constituencies) and to engage with them in accessing national level authorities with advocacy messages. Change target is openness of Iraqi authorities to victims and support their claims, which must increase over politically and exclusively oriented policy makers.

title.narrative: International policymakers have an increased understanding of the long term impact on civilians in Iraq from conflict, including on the use of explosive weapons in populated areas, drones and the linkages environment, peace and security through our research publications and outreach activities.

comment.narrative: The report by AIrwars and PAX was referenced in parliamentary debates in the Netherlands, as well as covered in a national newspaper. PAX provided input for an EU report on climate and conflict risks in the Middle East, including Iraq
Through the increased understanding of civilian and environmental harm from conflict we aim to increase the incentive and urgency for policymakers to address this harm.

comment.narrative: Main Iraqi partners have strong relations between them and with PAX, including long track-record of joint implementation in target geographic area, through a project with similar approaches (Local Peace Committees, 2015 - 2021). Involved partners also implement a variety of other projects, producing networking opportunities, experiences, and knowledge useful for the SCC project as well.
Throughout implementation, PAX aims for creating increased space for Iraqi partners to engage more in strategic program development.

Project development with third Iraqi partner could not be finalized in 2021, because of budget limitations and incomplete/in progress strategic planning. Contractual engagement with third Iraqi partner will commence in Q2 2022.

Per April 2022, PAX will start working with a third partner who will provide MHPSS services to citizens with mental health problems. A direct link will be established between activities by one of the local peacebuilding partners working under SO1 and identifying cases. International consortium partners contribute to qualitative development in realms of gender and human rights, primarily not through implementation nor contractual agreements.
